image.altText: Australian female soccer players jump high in celebration in front of a crowd of fans

items.synopsis: When will the Sam Kerr-captained side play again, and who will they be clashing with in the quarterfinals of the FIFA Women's World Cup?

title.children: The Matildas have won their World Cup match against Denmark. What happens next?

image.altText: A woman cries in front of a car.

items.synopsis: The woman who hosted the lunch that police believe resulted in three people dying from mushroom poisoning has spoken of her anguish at the deaths and denied doing anything wrong.

title.children: The woman who cooked a fatal meal for three people in Victoria's east says she's 'devastated' by the deaths

image.altText: A composite image of Christopher Pyne and Joe Hockey

items.synopsis: In Australia there has long been disquiet about the revolving door between high political office and big business. Look at the defence industry, for example, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: A new generation of former MPs has turned to big business

image.altText: An aerial photo of eight horses and foals jumping across a small creek in a national park.

items.synopsis: For some the brumby is a national icon that encapsulates what Australia is. For others it's a pest that's out of control.

title.children: Aerial shooting of brumbies to reduce numbers is back on the agenda. How did we get here?

image.altText: a woman running on the sand at a beach with a dog behind her

items.synopsis: The prolonged spell of warmer-than-normal weather in recent months is tipping 2023 as the firm favourite to set a new annual record.

title.children: New data reveals 2023 is on track for record heat — and next year should be even hotter

image.altText: Hayley Raso smiles and is hugged by her teammates

items.synopsis: The Matildas beat Denmark 2-0 to reach FIFA Women's World Cup quarterfinals. Earlier, England edges past Nigeria 4-2 on penalties in Brisbane.

title.children: 'We didn't get rattled': Matildas strike back after Danish assault to reach World Cup quarters

image.altText: Men in prisoner greens move scaffolding in front of home under construction.

items.synopsis: Correctional Services NSW has agreed to increase the number of inmate-built modular homes for the Aboriginal Housing Office, with a real need for five-bedroom homes and a workforce eager to build skills.

title.children: Inmates eager to ramp up home building for Indigenous communities

image.altText: People silhouetted against a white and blue KPMG logo.

items.synopsis: Newly compiled data reveals Defence has spent nearly $4 billion on large consulting firms over the past decade, more than all other Australian government departments combined.

title.children: 'Something's rotten': New analysis reveals $4 billion Defence department spend on consultancy firms

image.altText: a red Tesla Model 3 sedan is charged at a Tesla dealership with the Tesla logo shown on the dealership building in the back

items.synopsis: Tesla's chief financial officer, Zachary Kirkhorn, leaves the electric car-maker, and US stocks finish higher after last week's losses ahead of inflation report.  Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Elon Musk successor steps down from Tesla, US stocks regain lost ground ahead of inflation report

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: James Hardie has provided an interesting result early in the corporate reporting season. The Australian building materials producer, which is heavily focused on the US market, reported falling first quarter sales (-5% to $US954 million) but an increased underlying profit. The company's adjusted earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA) jumped 12% to $US279 million. The reason? A massive growth in profit margins. The company's adjusted EBITDA margin jumped from 24.9 to 29.2% over the past year. Both the company's US and Asia-Pacific fiber cement divisions posted record EBIT profit margins of 31.1% and 33.1% respectively. Those margins jumped 5.4 percentage points in the US and 7.5 percentage points in the Asia-Pacific region since its first quarter results a year ago. Slumping volumes saw the company's European building products division report a decrease in earnings, with rising costs keeping margins stagnant despite a steep rise in prices. Overall, the company ended up reporting a small (-3%) fall in its statutory net profit, which came in at $US157.8 million ($240 million).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: James Hardie grows profits on prices and margins as volumes fall

children.content: James Hardie
has provided an interesting result early in the corporate reporting season.
The Australian building materials producer, which is heavily focused on the US market, reported
falling first quarter sales (-5% to $US954 million)
but an
increased underlying profit
The company's adjusted earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA) jumped 12% to $US279 million.
The reason? A massive
growth in profit margins
The company's adjusted EBITDA margin jumped from 24.9 to 29.2% over the past year.
Both the company's US and Asia-Pacific fiber cement divisions posted
record EBIT profit margins
of 31.1% and 33.1% respectively.
Those margins jumped 5.4 percentage points in the US and 7.5 percentage points in the Asia-Pacific region since its first quarter results a year ago.
Slumping volumes saw the company's European building products division report a decrease in earnings, with rising costs keeping margins stagnant despite a steep rise in prices.
Overall, the company ended up reporting
a small (-3%) fall in its statutory net profit
, which came in at $US157.8 million ($240 million).

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, welcome to the ABC's markets blog. I'm Sue Lannin. The big news this morning is the resignation of Tesla's chief financial officer Zachary Kirkhorn. Investors are worried because he's been seen as a possible successor to Tesla founder Elon Musk. Reuters reports that his departure has raised concerns about a succession plan at the world's most valuable carmaker. Tesla shares fell 3.5 per cent on the news. And US stocks had a good night after last week's sell-off, with the S & P 500 and the Nasdaq ending four days of losses. Warren Buffet's investment firm Berkshire Hathaway jumped to a record high after the company reported its quarterly operating profit topped $US10 billion ($15.2 billion) for the first time. Later this week, the US consumer price index will be released, a key piece of information for the US Federal Reserve and its next move on interest rates. US consumer prices saw their smallest annual increase in two years in June. Coming up today, we will get a reading of consumer confidence from Westpac and the Melbourne Institute and the National Australia Bank releases its latest business confidence survey. And building materials maker James Hardie reports its first quarter profit. Grab a coffee and let's go.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Tesla finance chief steps down

children.content: Good morning, welcome to the ABC's markets blog. I'm Sue Lannin.
The big news this morning is the resignation of Tesla's chief financial officer Zachary Kirkhorn.
Investors are worried because he's been seen as a possible successor to Tesla founder Elon Musk.
Reuters reports that his departure has raised concerns about a succession plan at the world's most valuable carmaker.
Tesla shares fell 3.5 per cent on the news.
And US stocks had a good night after last week's sell-off, with the S
P 500 and the Nasdaq ending four days of losses.
Warren Buffet's investment firm Berkshire Hathaway
jumped to a record high after the company reported its quarterly operating profit topped $US10 billion ($15.2 billion) for the first time.
Later this week, the US consumer price index will be released, a key piece of information for the US Federal Reserve and its next move on interest rates.
US consumer prices saw their smallest annual increase in two years in June.
Coming up today, we will get a reading of consumer confidence from Westpac and the Melbourne Institute and the National Australia Bank releases its latest business confidence survey.
And building materials maker James Hardie reports its first quarter profit.
Grab a coffee and let's go.

items.synopsis: In the 1967 referendum on Indigenous rights, the NSW electorate of Cowper recorded one of the highest "no" votes. Now, Gumbaynggirr elders are reflecting on past lessons as they prepare for the second Indigenous referendum in their lifetime.

title.children: 'Feels like hatred': Meet the town that voted 'no' in the last Indigenous referendum

image.altText: An Australian para-cyclist smiles and waves as she holds her gold medal in her hand.

items.synopsis: Emily Petricola doubles Australia's gold medal tally at the cycling worlds but Logan Martin has to settle for silver in the BMX freestyle.

title.children: Para-cyclist Emily Petricola claims second Aussie gold at world cycling titles

image.altText: Steph Catley hands the Matildas' captain's armband to Sam Kerr during Australia's 2-0 win over Denmark in the Women's World Cup.

items.synopsis: Sam Kerr returned to playing action and England survived a massive scare to beat Nigeria on penalties, despite having their young star sent off. Here are the five quick hits.

title.children: Five quick hits: Sam Kerr returns to triumphant Matildas as her club teammate sees red for England

image.altText: Hayley Raso (C) of Australia celebrates scoring the second goal for Australia

title.children: How the internet reacted to the Matildas' 2-0 win over Denmark

image.altText: A man and three women walk along a dirt track in outback Australia.

items.synopsis: A date for the Voice to Parliament referendum is yet to be announced because "there are still so many" Australians that need to be reached, Labor senator Malarndirri McCarthy tells Q+A during a special broadcast from Garma Festival.

title.children: 'The earlier the better, prime minister': Voice referendum date yet to be set amid promise of no delays

image.altText: Men arrested, children removed in global child sexual abuse investigation

items.synopsis: The Australian Federal Police reveals details of the joint FBI operation targeting child abuse material on the dark web.

title.children: Murder of two FBI agents leads to Australian sex abuse operation, removal of children

image.altText: America Ferrera in a white dress standing in front of a pink Barbie convertible with Barbie written behind her

items.synopsis: America Ferrera has gone viral in recent weeks for her feminist monologue in Barbie, which is a turning point in the film.

title.children: Loved America Ferrera's Barbie monologue? She's been building up to it her whole career

image.altText: Memorial to five boys killed in Russell Island house fire with ball, teddybears resting against fence that has a drawing on it

items.synopsis: A Russell Island soccer club will observe a minute's silence to honour the memory of five children and their father, who died tragically in a house fire over the weekend.

title.children: 'It's just unbelievable': Shocked community grieves friends killed in devastating house fire

image.altText: A pile of Australian dollar coins on top of several bank notes

items.synopsis: Despite years of trade surpluses and a budget surplus to boot, the Australian dollar is on the slide once more — and it's all thanks to commodities and interest rates, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: The Australian dollar is on the slide, and no-one knows just how low it will go

image.altText: Lee Hsien Loong speaks during a press conference.

items.synopsis: Does a string of scandals plaguing Singapore's government show that the system of oversight is working, or that such issues are inevitable without independent checks and balances?

title.children: 'Whiter than white': Why Singapore's recent spate of scandals have rocked the country

image.altText: Volodymyr Zelensky sits in a brown leather chair with a Ukrainian flag behind him

items.synopsis: Ukraine's intelligence agency detains a woman allegedly helping Russian authorities plan an air strike on an area Mr Zelenskyy visited last month.

title.children: Russian 'spy' arrested in Ukraine over role in alleged plot to blow up President Volodymyr Zelenskyy

image.altText: A composite image of a man with glasses in a suit and tie, and a woman with long hair.

items.synopsis: The head of an inquiry into judicial fairness as part of the prosecution of Bruce Lehrmann is now the one under the spotlight.

title.children: 'Significant lapse of judgement': ACT government slams early release of report into Bruce Lehrmann's prosecution

image.altText: Martin, Selena and Steve look at something beyond the camera with a shocked expression as they stand on a stage.

items.synopsis: With the most Oscar nominations in history, Meryl Streep hardly needs an introduction. But if you're yet to watch Only Murders in the Building, here's everything you need to know ahead of season three.

title.children: Meryl Streep has joined Only Murders in the Building. Here's your guide to the 'cosy crime' series

image.altText: Penny Wong, wearing a floral wreath in her hair, kneels next to Kiribati children holding Australian flags

items.synopsis: Australia will require both climate and gender objectives in much of its foreign aid spending, under a new framework aimed at strengthening Australia's influence in the Indo-Pacific.

title.children: China, climate and gender equality: Australia's new foreign aid policy aimed at building influence in Pacific

image.altText: NSW RFS battle a blaze at Wentworth Falls in the Blue Mountains, August 3, 2015.

items.synopsis: The first recommendation suggested by counsel assisting the coronial inquiry is the creation of national standards for firefighting truck cabins, with "three tragic incidents" highlighting the need to reassess safety.

title.children: Firefighting truck standards lead closing submissions at NSW Bushfires Coronial Inquiry

image.altText: A man in a camouflage jacket with his arms crossed is spoken to in a police interview room

items.synopsis: Family and friends of the slain teen clapped and sighed with relief in court in Dubbo this morning when Craig Rumsby, 56, was jailed for at least 24 years.

title.children: For 24 years this man got away with murder. Today Michelle Bright's family finally saw justice

image.altText: nurses and midwives at a trike for better pay and conditions

items.synopsis: The vote by the NSW Nurses and Midwives' Association staves off industrial action, but the union says its members recognise 4 per cent isn't enough and vow to continue their fight for better pay.

title.children: NSW nurses accept government's 4pc pay rise in narrow vote 'driven by cost of living'

image.altText: An aerial photo of a green cotton picker harvesting cotton.

items.synopsis: With the NSW government chipping in $36 million, the project at Moree aims to produce green hydrogen, renewable ammonia and solar power to lower fertiliser and fuel emissions by displacing 1.4 million litres of imported diesel.

title.children: Big funding injection, ambitious deadline for Australian 'first' project to decarbonise cotton growing

image.altText: An Asian woman and man smile for a photo as their picture is taken at a restaurant

items.synopsis: A Melbourne couple charged with enslaving a woman at their Melbourne home for 10 months has been ordered to stand trial, after several court delays and changes to their legal representation.

title.children: Melbourne couple to stand trial accused of modern-day slavery

image.altText: A burger on a plate, with lettuce and tomato.

items.synopsis: Is eating a beef burger worse for your health than eating a lean grass-fed steak? And how much red meat should we really be eating? Katherine Livingstone weighs the evidence.

title.children: Is eating a beef burger worse for your health than eating a lean grass-fed steak?

image.altText: Typhoon Khanun

items.synopsis: The South Korean government has announced an emergency evacuation of participants and volunteers of the World Scout Jamboree ahead of a typhoon forecast to hit the country.

title.children: 36,000 scouts to be evacuated from South Korean jamboree ahead of Typhoon Khanun

image.altText: An illustration of a boy staring out a window from behind.

items.synopsis: Almost 33 per cent of Australians feel disconnected socially, and one in six feels severely lonely, according to a landmark study. But there are ways to feel less alone.

title.children: 'They feel really ashamed': Millions of Australians are lonely, but many find it hard to admit
